body: @himanshug any reason we are rolling our own parser / lexer instead of levering antlr or something similar?
Should we remove AlwaysHavingSpec then since there isn't any real use case of it?

@xvrl mostly because parser/lexer is simple/small for this grammar (see the number of lines with real code in Lexer/Parser class), having it implemented here means less magic. All the rest of the code would be needed whether you used ANTLR or not.
are you +1ing the removal of AlwaysHavingSpec?  What about NeverHavingSpec?

@guobingkun There's always testing purposes (and who knows how all people could be using it in the wild). Unless it causes issues or conflicts or does not work as intended then I'd say leave it present in code, but remove the default as per this PR.
Just noticed it seems to be absent from the list beneath.
@binlijin can you try running on a dedicated machine, the difference you are seeing could just be due to clock rate / temperature fluctuations on your laptop is what @drcrallen is saying
Sorry, I don't understand the context of the previous comment.  What's "it" that is absent, and what's the list?

@stevemns Thanks for the contrib! Do you mind filling out the individual CLA real quick?

http://druid.io/community/cla.html
@rasahner The default value removed in this PR is not present in the explicit naming annotation beneath the modified line.
CLA is filled out. I have also updated the verbiage to include additional information about the middle manager host name limitations.
@rasahner  I think we should add it as "always" type so that users who want to use it for whatever reasons can still use it.
@b-slim @gianm Based on prevailing opinion, I'll remove the injective property from this PR; isInjective() isn't really being used by LookupExtractionFn or JavascriptExtractionFn either, presently.
:+1: after travis
@fjy this is ready to go can you merge it please
@himanshug can you give this final lookup

@gianm 

I've revised the PR to avoid persisting null columns. 

IndexGeneratorJob and Sink have been changed to remember dimension orders outside of/across their individual indexes.

I also added a change to IndexIO's v8 to v9 conversion function, I noticed in some testing/debugging that filtering on a null value would fail in some cases if I converted null dim values within dimension to empty strings before persisting an IncrementalIndex. A check for empty string values was added so the "dimensions with null values" logic would be handled properly.
@gianm @himanshug Do you have any more feedback for this?

Hi @b-slim ,

I'm trying to use this Graphite emitter, but I can't see any events coming.
My configuration looks like this:

```
druid.monitoring.monitors=["com.metamx.metrics.JvmMonitor"]
druid.emitter=graphite
druid.emitter.graphite.hostname=graphite
druid.emitter.graphite.port=2003
druid.emitter.graphite.eventConverter={"type":"whiteList", "namespacePrefix": "druid", "ignoreHostname":false, "ignoreServiceName":false}
```

The last line in the log file says:

```
2015-12-15T09:42:55,016 INFO [GraphiteEmitter-0] io.druid.emitter.graphite.GraphiteEmitter - trying to connect to graphite server
```

I've also checked that I'm able to send events to the graphite server using:

```
echo "test.blabla.stats 42 `date +%s`" | nc graphite 2003
```

Can you please help me debug this?

Thanks!
I've added the "always" type to the list.
@rasahner LGTM, pls squash your commits.
@xvrl i agree with "understandability and extensibility" point, I will try to generate lexer/parser with antlr.

@spektom first please note that the module is using the pickled protocol, which is port 2004 by default.
please read [this](http://graphite.readthedocs.org/en/latest/feeding-carbon.html#the-pickle-protocol) and tell me if it is not working.
squashed (didn't before in case I had to close/reopen for travis)

Events are still not coming to Graphite, though.

Graphite emitter can send alerts so it will look for another emitter to forwarded to.
@spektom, if you want to get alerting on logs please set `druid.emitter.graphite.alertEmitters=["logging"]`
by the way you can use other kind of emitters to emit alerting.
If you want to ignore all alerts you can redirect this to the noop emitter   `druid.emitter.graphite.alertEmitters=["noop"]`
@spektom is it working ?
bouncing for travis.

@b-slim It's working finally! (our pickle endpoint was set to another port in graphite)

Speaking from experience, extensions which depend on other extensions tend to get tricky. With how the module classloader isolation works in Druid you often cannot access the classes cross-extension in the ways that you would hope. As such, it would make more sense to have anything that is shaded be in the system classloader (or at least the same classloader as all the other core druid stuff).

This is very much so worth discussing on how to best approach the "how can we upgrade our libraries independently of other toolsets" question

Thanks for your feedback @drcrallen . Just to avoid confusion on my side: My idea was not to create a new Druid extension, but instead to build a simple basic Java module (the term 'module' as in Maven module) containing all the shaded stuff. The core of Druid (and probably then also all extensions) would then have that java package as some simple build dependency. I assume that then this module would be present in the classloader of the Druid core stuff - or would there still be a problem? I will investigate into the usage of classloaders in Druid... that's also some new terrain for me.

I hope that I will have some time for first experiments at the end of the week.

The "ideal" solution would be to have the classloaders properly isolated such that different java library versions can be used in different parts of the data stack... but the tricky part there comes in when they have to communicate across classLoaders. Otherwise you'll get into a case where you get an error where class `x.y.Z` cannot be assigned to class `x.y.Z`... which is very confusing to see in an error until you realize they were loaded through mutually exclusive classloaders.

Has anyone out there been able to solve hadoop library problems without resorting to shading?

That's a good point. Give me some time to think about that, I really need to get a better understanding which module or extension first use specific classes and where exactly the Hadoop dependency jumps in. I believe it should be possible to perform isolation via class loaders - but yes, it could get tricky.
@cheddar and @rasahner  thanks,  done

@xvrl generated stuff with ANTLR .
@rasahner comments addressed

user can see the segments information before/after the task using the http endpoint `/datasources/{dataSourceName}/segments` and make the decision on retrying or not based on that ? they might have to wait for `druid.manager.segments.pollDuration` after the task finishes (with success/failure).

Hello @drcrallen, 

Is Spark indexer implementation you've mentioned available somewhere? We'd like to have a look at it, if that's possible. We have vast experience with tuning Spark for different workloads, and we have lots of data to test it, so we might help get it fixed.

Thanks!
@spektom Yep, getting you access.

By popular request, and since development is more on the spark side than the druid-extension side right now, I have made https://github.com/metamx/druid-spark-batch open to the public for general testing / alpha interest.

I would _not_ consider it production ready yet, so please do not expect it to be free of corner cases or support easy upgrades. And version upgrades at this point have _zero_ backwards compatibility guarantees (I'm _hoping_ nothing will change, but not willing to stamp anything as a long term support yet).

My bandwidth for answering general support questions is severely limited, but will gladly make time to collaborate on improvements.

If you're trying to get it to work with arbitrary hadoop versions or spark versions I cannot lend assistance.  But if you have some changes that will help it work with arbitrary hadoop or spark versions I'm very happy to help get them in.
:+1: after travis
I think you're right, although in my case it took ~40 minutes for nodes to go down after receiving SIGTERM. Anyway, any chances of this being resolved anytime soon?
Absence of logging is probably because of https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/1387 not being in stable yet.

@gianm hmm... so the flow would be like..
1) user sends overlord request to get list of DataSegments for desired interval
2) then sends the hadoopIndexTask and puts the above list in the task json
then even if user retries same task it would stay idempotent ?

also, I think user will have to provide interval as well so that we can do the VersionedIntervalTimeline stuff to create WindowedDataSegment, I don't think user can take the pain of doing all that.
@gianm implementing that idea is trivial, see https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2109 . let me know if that sounds OK.
:+1: after https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/1861#discussion_r47867147 is resolved.
@jon-wei this might be in conflict with https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/1995 , can you review/merge that one? I think it is ready and very useful to me in many use cases.

that is worrying.
@cheddar how about only returning a flag telling whether "partial" data is being returned or make this feature configurable based on some query config parameter?
@himanshug Merged your other PR, resolving conflicts

I don't think the cache updating post-runnable code path _needs_ to be async. I honestly don't remember why I made it that way to begin with. Instead of making a complex workaround to make it partly synchronous, can we just make the post runnable called inside of futureWithString ?
Thanks for the feedback @himanshug , I removed PowerMock and created local temp files for the unit test.

Hmmm, I think the issue you are reporting actually is because of the "intervals" field in the topN

If you issue the same query with "intervals": "2015-12-09T15:00:00/P1D", or a much less granular interval, what do you see?
@jon-wei see if you need to make changes similar to https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2112
@himanshug This one's fine in that respect, the result output won't change since the query uses default analysis types
I think @drcrallen would be right. Returning ListenableFuture expecting get() will return value only when all listeners are executed is not possible. I'll revised this.
@xvrl @drcrallen I've moved all logic into single Runnable. I couldn't sure current lock scheme is safe but I've not modified anything on that part.

I have been thinking a little bit about solving the issue with some ClassLoader magic. One big issue here is that the mappers and reducers will be instantiated by Hadoop, of course the offending jars from Hadoop then are already present in the ClassLoader. 

So one idea would be to implement "delegating" mapper and reducer classes, which first setup a properly build ClassLoader with Druid provided jars of the problematic classes. This ClassLoader would also need to be implemented such that it first looks into its own list of jars and then delegates to the parent class loader (I think the normal behaviour is the opposite way round). At least it should have a blacklist of classes which should not be delegated to its parent.

Then those delegating mapper and reducer could instantiate the real Druid mapper and reducer using its special ClassLoader. The map/reduce methods of the encapsulting mapper/reducer then would delegate the work to the loaded mapper/reducer.

Any thoughts about that? Does this make sense to anybody?
I've seen this same problem occur on multiple test runs
@fjy can you link to any of them?

https://travis-ci.org/druid-io/druid/jobs/97624306

@b-slim : https://travis-ci.org/druid-io/druid/jobs/97728606#L4589 something weird in tests

So, at a high level I think the idea behind this PR is fine, but I don't like the centralization of the logic within the Toolchest. I think it'd be nice to have another layer which is doing query optimization and rewrite that we can extend in the future to do some types of query optimization. 

If we treat this new layer as the start of a query planner for Druid, there should be no need for the optimize flag and the planner should do these things automatically.

You can probably ignore most of my code review comments as they concern what I was thinking as I was reading the code.
Should be solved by https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2063 via https://github.com/metamx/java-util/pull/28
